content: hey guys Happy New Year why lock here so
there's been a lot of chatter lately on the tabletop crafters guild group about
airbrushing I bought an airbrush about two years ago and I've been using it on
the channel a lot ever since so I figured I'd put together some tips and
lessons and shortcuts and recommendations that I've picked up over
that time to be clear this is catered toward people who have never used and
don't own an airbrush and are wondering if it's a worthwhile addition to their
crafting toolkit so there's links in the video description below for all the
products I'm about to reference I use all of them and they all perform great
for me their Amazon links and so if you choose to use those exact links your
purchase is exactly the same cost and delivery and all that the only
difference is I get a small kickback for having referred you so easy way to
support the channel at no extra cost to you if you want to all right so let's go
explore airbrushing so this is the kid I started with the brand is master it was
awesome for doing base coats and blends not really capable of fine detail work
but perfect for learning the basics I've since upgraded to an Iwata Eclipse which
you'll see me used in this video but I still use the same compressor from this
cheap kit I use this respirator when I'm airbrushing actually the paint spray
itself isn't an issue but later on the cleaning solution was an irritant gave
me sneezing fits for days but this thing problem solved
link in the description below so attach the hose to your airbrush and the
compressor and then dial the pressure so that it's at 22 psi that's what worked
good for me there's the tolerance I'm sure 20 or 25
probably works fine but for me 22 was good to go
so this airbrush is a double action gravity-fed airbrush double action means
that the trigger has two manipulations push the button in to start the air flow
pull the trigger back to retract the needle and allow paint to flow the
farther back you pull the trigger the more paint will spray gravity-fed means
there's a cup attached to the brush in which you pour your mixture as opposed
to siphon fed so let's do a miniature I like to lay down a sacrificial piece of
paper and have a rinsing cup of water a jar of clean water that will never be
mixed and a garbage pot I usually don't pry my miniatures have
done a couple hundred miniatures now plastic and metal and never had any
issues but suppose you want to Prime with your airbrush this army painter
brand brushed on primer is great you mix it like any other paint and here's how I
like to do that Vallejo airbrush flow improver water
works but this stuff I found prevents dry out at the tip much better I also
have a retired junk brush that I use for all mixing in the pot so a couple drops
of that into the well then squeeze in some paint about ten parts paint to one
part flow improver then I dip my junk brush in water just enough to load it
with a bit of water and mix it all up the tests I use for the right fitness is
to tilt the airbrush back and forth and look at the surface of the mixture if
it's too thick like paint right out of the pot then it won't move if it's thin
enough the surface will begin to move due to gravity you want about the
consistency of whole-milk you don't want it to be too watery to restate
everything I just said another way start it out being too thick and gradually
added drop a flow improver at a time until the thickness just breaks and
starts behaving more like a liquid that's the sweet spot you do not want to
over thin so watch this push down to start the air flow and pull back for
paint now try and do a very fine line you see that splotch at the beginning
that's called spider ring and it generally happens if your paint is too
thinned out and in fact that's what I've done here mix this a bit thin to show
what can happen anyway you can also see the thin line I can draw that's the
iwata in action the master airbrush probably won't be able to do that so
here's a tea renewed hormone aunt few inches away from model but half throttle
on the trigger and we apply a coat whole thing takes about I don't know 10
seconds and you get a hundred percent perfectly smooth coverage with no
clogging of details due to the thin application
so them on a base coated with army painter skeleton bone so again we're
gonna put in our flow improver then the paint and before mixing here we do the
tilt test you can see way too thick because it hasn't been mixed yet and
you'll get the neck for this after a few tries as to what the right thinness is
so again several inches away from the model we're gonna start with low
throttle and add more as you go if you start seeing a wet sheen on it that
means you're probably putting on too much at once it's better to dust it and
do maybe two or three light passes so here's a closer look at it under two
different amounts of light and you can see it's just a really buttery smooth
coat you have no brushstrokes there's no
chalky finish to it that's just an advantage of the airbrush and it took
all of eight to 10 seconds to do this base coat also included here is a blue
ultramarine space marine and I've included it so you can see the smooth
pauldron again it's not a chalky finish there's no brushstrokes all the armor
plating like on the legs very smooth so again huge time saver and makes you look
a lot better than you really are so you may recall we've used the airbrush many
times before on the channel you might remember doing a brown green gradient
for the riverbed and the functional waterfall back in episode 74
here's that in action also it's very handy for adding depth to terrain simply
by tossing some black in the pot and tracing all the interior corners of a
feature here's a building from a forthcoming episode so just a quick line
of army painter black to kind of tie things together or remember the fuel
depot from episode 60 here it is just add a line of black there at the bottom
- well first of all help hide any glue or incomplete flocking and create a nice
little shadow effect so that basic master airbrush kit can be and was used
to achieve all of this now cleaning the airbrush you can easily
do a lot of unnecessary work by doing things out of order so here's the
process I go through takes about three minutes flood the well with water mix it
up and then dump into your garbage pot blow out the little bit that's left and
you'll have a thin film of paint still in there wipe it out with an old t-shirt
or rag at this point it looks pretty clean but it's not pour in your airbrush
cleaner this is the brand I recommend again link in the video description
below then swirl that around with the brush and make sure it touches all of
the well there's still some paint residue clinging in there and this
cleaner breaks it up really good spray a bit then plug the tip with your rag and
spray some more it should bubble up from reverse-flow like this dump all the
excess spray the little bit that remains and wipe out with your rag third and
final step add more cleaner remove the needle and blow the cleaner through
again you can also do the reverse bubbling thing so I don't take it apart
and soak the pieces in water or cleaner I've probably cleaned my out water brush
this way fifty times now and it still performs just like new also they make
actual mist catching pots that you can use to blow excess fluid and really
that's the right way to do it but I didn't want to buy one if you do link is
below now I'm still very much an amateur one channel run by an expert that I
really like is next level painting he's got tons of great tutorials there for
airbrush usage huge backlog of videos to go through great content also there's a
new channel in the guild community here recently started up devious Dungeons
painting and he's doing tutorials which often include using an airbrush so
subscribe there and help get that one off the ground too for all you 3d
printers out there don't forget to check out heroes hoard where you can get true
tiles models as well as a ton of other excellent fantasy related scenery hi my
Locke thank you for joining me and I'll see you next time
you
